# How did this happen?

Lesson from Chris Eagle.

Now move to test.c

		#include <stdio.h>
		#include <unistd.h>
		int main() {
			char buf[10000];
		memset(buf, 'a', 9999);
		buf[9999] = 0;
		printf("%s", buf);
		write(1, "How did this happen\n", 20);
		}

So this appears to type 9999 a's and then "How did this happen"

		gcc test.c -o test
		./test
		 did this happen
			

However, this program runs a whole lot oof a's then How did this happen followed by more a's

So... How did this happen?

printf is piling a's into user space buffer; only after the buffer is full it "flushes" (forcing system call to be made)

Libc in the process of closing out, there's a's left in the buffer so they too get flushed out

BLUF: Don't mix buffered IO with unbuffered IO
